choices.text: Increased pulsatality index in umbilical art

questions.text: On Doppler the most omnious sign indicating fetal compromise is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Absent diastolic flow Absent diastolic flow in the umbilical artery on Doppler is the most ominous sign of fetal compromise. It indicates a severe restriction in placental blood flow, which impairs oxygen and nutrient delivery to the fetus. This finding is often associated with advanced placental insufficiency, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), and hypoxia. Absent diastolic flow suggests that the fetus is at high risk for adverse outcomes, including intrauterine fetal demise, and usually warrants urgent intervention, such as delivery, depending on the gestational age and clinical scenario. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) Increased pulsatility index in umbilical artery: An increased pulsatility index (PI) in the umbilical artery reflects increased placental resistance to blood flow. While it is an early indicator of placental insufficiency, it is not as ominous as absent diastolic flow. A rising PI often precedes absent or reversed diastolic flow, making it a concerning but less severe finding. (B) Increased S/D blood flow ratio: An increased systolic-to-diastolic (S/D) ratio in the umbilical artery indicates heightened resistance to blood flow within the placenta. This is a sign of developing placental dysfunction but is not as critical as absent diastolic flow. Persistently elevated S/D ratios may eventually lead to absent or reversed diastolic flow if placental insufficiency worsens. (C) Increased cerebral artery flow: Increased blood flow in the middle cerebral artery (MCA) is a compensatory response by the fetus, known as the "brain-sparing effect." It reflects redistribution of blood flow to vital organs in response to hypoxia. While it signals fetal compromise, it is not as directly life-threatening as absent diastolic flow in the umbilical artery.

questions.text: AG2P, woman at 35 weeks pregnancy complains of decreased fetal movement. Next step in Mgt is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Whenever a pregnant female complains of decreased fetal movement A nonreactive NST earlier was being followed by a CST(contraction stress test) to confirm the diagnosis of hypoxia but CST is associated with risk of initiating labor and hence these days a nonreactive NST is being followed by a biophysical score(Manning score) Clinical assessment of a woman with Decreased fetal movement should include review of symphysis fundal height measurements and a no stress test (NST) should be performed to exclude immediate fetal compromise. In the absence of a fetal heart rate tracing warranting emergency delivery, an ultrasound examination for fetal biometry and amniotic fluid volume should be obtained, ideally within 24 hours. Fetal morphology is assessed if not recently performed.

questions.text: Which is the most significant finding in cardiotocography for detection of fetal hypoxia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Category 3 pattern is considered abnormal because studies have denibstrated an increased risk for fetal hypoxic academia when the diagnostic criteria for a category III pattern are present. Category III pattern is defined by: Absent baseline FHR variability (ie,amplitude undetectable) and any of the following. Bradycardia recurrent late decelerations, recurrent variable decelerations A sinusoidal pattern is an oscillating pattern which is typically smooth and regular. It has a relatively fixed period of 2-5 cycles per minute and has an amplitude of between 5 and 15bpm around the baseline rate. Baseline variability is absent and there are no acceleration. It is typically reflective of severe anemia, with hemoglobin levels below 50 gm/L It is considered ominous and indicates severe hypoxia which needs immediate termination Absent Variability of FHR + Bradycardia OR Late deceleration OR Recurrent Variable deceleration

questions.text: Sinusoidal heart rate pattern is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sinusoidal Pattern: Stable baseline heart rate of 120 to 160 beats/min with regular oscillations Amplitude of 5 to 15 beat/min(rarely greater) Long-term variability frequency of 2 to 5 cycles per min Fixed or flat short term variability Oscillation of the siusoidal wave form above or below or baseline Absence of accelerations Causes of Sinusoidal pattern Serious fetal anemia due to Rh-isoimmunisation/rupture vasa previa/fetomaternal hemorrhage/twin-to-twin transfusion Drug eperidine,morphine,alphaprodine and butorphanol Amnionitis Fetal distress Umbilical cord occlusion

questions.text: During 1st stage of labor,FHR should be auscultated in low risk pregnancy after every:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Record the FHR during and immediately after a uterine contraction at least every 30 minutes during the active phase of the first stage of labor and at least every 15 minutes during the second stage. If risk factors for fetal compromise are present, the FHR is determined, evaluated, and recorded preferably before, during, and after a uterine contraction at least every 15 minutes during the active phase of the first stage of labor and at least every 5 minutes during the second stage.

Correct Answer (A) NST with AFI The Modified Biophysical Profile (BPS) consists of the Non-Stress Test (NST) combined with the Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI). This combination allows for the assessment of fetal heart rate reactivity (NST) and the amount of amniotic fluid, which is a marker of placental function and fetal well-being. The AFI helps to detect conditions like oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios, which may indicate fetal compromise. By focusing on these two parameters, the modified BPS is a simplified, effective test to assess fetal health, especially in high-risk pregnancies. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (B) NST with fetal breathing: While fetal breathing is an important part of the full Biophysical Profile (BPP), it is not included in the modified BPS. Fetal breathing movements are assessed in a complete BPP, which includes NST, fetal movements, fetal tone, and AFI. The modified BPS simplifies this by only combining NST and AFI, omitting the assessment of fetal breathing. (C) NST with fetal movement: Fetal movement is another component of the full BPP but is not included in the modified BPS. The full BPP assesses the presence of fetal movements as an indicator of fetal well-being, but the modified version only considers NST and AFI to streamline the evaluation process, focusing on heart rate reactivity and amniotic fluid volume. (D) NST with fetal tone: Fetal tone, like fetal movements and breathing, is part of the full Biophysical Profile but is not included in the modified BPS. The modified version is a simpler assessment that combines NST with AFI, leaving out fetal tone, which requires more detailed observation and is not always as readily assessed as the other components.

choices.text: The Doppler studies indicate that the fetus is doing well.
With advancing gestational age the S/D ratio is supposed to rise.
These Doppler findings are normal in someone who smokes.
Reverse diastolic flow is normal as a patient approaches full term.
The Doppler studies are worrisome and indicate that the fetal status is deteriorating.

questions.text: A 26-year-old G1P0 patient at 34 weeks gestation is being evaluated with Doppler ultrasound studies of the fetal umbilical arteries. The patient is a healthy smoker. Her fetus has shown evidence of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) on previous ultrasound examinations. The Doppler studies currently show that the systolic to diastolic ratio (S/D) in the umbilical arteries is much higher than it was on her last ultrasound 3 weeks ago and there is now reverse diastolic flow. Which of the following is correct information to share with the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Simple continuous-wave Doppler ultrasound can be used to display flow velocity waveforms as a function of time. With increased gestational age, in normal pregnancy there is an increase in end-diastolic flow velocity relative to peak systolic velocity, which causes the S/D ratio to decrease with advancing gestation. An increase in S/D ra?o is associated with increased resistance in the placental vascular bed as can be noted in preeclampsia or fetal growth retardation. Nicotine and maternal smoking have also been reported to increase the S/D ratio. Many studies document the value of umbilical Doppler flow studies in recognition of fetal compromise. It seems that the S/D ratio increases as the fetal condition deteriorates; this is most severe in cases of absent or reversed end diastolic flow. In normal twins, the S/D ratio falls

questions.text: A primigravida with preeclampsia at 37 weeks is being induced with oxytocin. The following graph is seen during her monitoring. Which of the following will not be done for her management ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Amnioinfusion Amnioinfusion is not indicated in the management of a primigravida with preeclampsia at 37 weeks being induced with oxytocin unless there are signs of oligohydramnios or fetal distress specifically due to meconium aspiration or cord compression. Amnioinfusion involves the introduction of sterile fluid into the amniotic sac to relieve umbilical cord compression and increase the amount of amniotic fluid. In a case of preeclampsia, the primary concern is maternal and fetal hemodynamic stability, and interventions like oxytocin for induction, left lateral position, and oxygen are more directly related to addressing the symptoms of preeclampsia and promoting uterine contractions. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) Left lateral position: The left lateral position is a common intervention used to improve maternal perfusion and reduce the impact of supine hypotension syndrome, particularly in the third trimester of pregnancy. This position helps increase blood flow to the uterus, kidney, and other vital organs by relieving pressure on the inferior vena cava, which can be compromised in preeclampsia, leading to better fetal oxygenation and circulation. (B) Give oxygen: Administering oxygen is an appropriate intervention in a preeclamptic patient to improve oxygen delivery to both the mother and fetus, especially if there are signs of fetal distress or hypoxemia. Oxygen supplementation can also help manage symptoms of pulmonary edema, which can develop in severe preeclampsia or eclampsia, improving overall maternal and fetal well-being. (D) CS (Caesarean Section): A Caesarean Section (CS) may be indicated for the delivery of the fetus in preeclamptic patients, particularly if there is fetal distress, failure to progress in labor, or signs of maternal complications like eclampsia or abruptio placentae. In this scenario, if there is evidence of fetal compromise (such as abnormal fetal heart rate patterns) or failure of induction with oxytocin, a CS may be required for the safety of both the mother and the fetus.

questions.text: What does the following finding on the fetal monitoring strip suggest?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fetal anemia A sinusoidal pattern on continuous FHR monitoring indicates fetal anemia. Although this can sometimes be confused with a pseudosinusoidal pattern, when there is a true sinusoidal pattern, it is considered to be nonreassuring because it indicates fetal anemia. Given the small fetal blood volume, a sinusoidal pattern should prompt an emergent delivery (as fast as possible) by the obstetrician. Fetal anemia in this case was most likely caused by rupture of the fetal vessels (vasa previa) upon rupture of the membranes. Uteroplacental insufficiency is not associated with a sinusoidal FHR tracing. Late decelerations are the typical fetal tracing finding when uteroplacental insufficiency occurs. These can be subtle or overt but if they are recurrent with every contraction for more than three contractions, the obstetrician should undertake immediate intervention. Cord compression causes variable decelerations, rather than a sinusoidal pattern. This can usually be resolved with an intraamniotic infusion using an intrauterine pressure catheter. By instilling the uterus with fluid, the cord has more protection from compression during uterine contractions. Head compression during labor is usually associated with early decelerations that start before a contraction and recover by the end of the contraction. A true sinusoidal tracing is never normal and is indicative of nonreassuring fetal status.

choices.text: A 23-year-old G1P0 at 42 weeks is undergoing inducon of labor. She is receiving intravenous oxytocin. She complains that her contractions are very painful and seem to be continuous
A patient at 41 weeks is undergoing NST. Her NST is reactive and reassuring
A laboring patient at 40 weeks gestation presents with spontaneous rupture of membranes. Bedside ultrasonography shows no measurable pockets of amniotic fluid..
A preeclamptic patient at 33 weeks gestation with IUGR is undergoing induction of labor.

questions.text: Which clinical scenario matches with the findings in the NST graph
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A patient at 41 weeks is undergoing NST. Her NST is reactive and reassuring In this scenario, the Non-Stress Test (NST) is reactive and reassuring, which indicates a healthy fetal heart rate with adequate variability and accelerations. This is considered a normal finding and suggests that the fetus is well-oxygenated and not experiencing any immediate signs of distress. In the context of 41 weeks gestation, a reactive NST provides reassurance that the fetus is tolerating the intrauterine environment well, even though the pregnancy is prolonged. The absence of concerning patterns like late decelerations or absence of variability suggests the fetus is not at risk at this stage. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) A 23-year-old G1P0 at 42 weeks is undergoing induction of labor. She is receiving intravenous oxytocin. She complains that her contractions are very painful and seem to be continuous: In this case, continuous painful contractions could suggest uterine hyperstimulation, which can lead to abnormal fetal heart rate patterns, such as decelerations or variable decelerations. If this were the case, the NST would show non-reassuring patterns indicating fetal distress. The patient's complaints of continuous contractions indicate that close monitoring is required to prevent over-augmentation with oxytocin, which can lead to uterine hyperstimulation and compromise fetal oxygenation. (C) A laboring patient at 40 weeks gestation presents with spontaneous rupture of membranes. Bedside ultrasonography shows no measurable pockets of amniotic fluid: This scenario suggests oligohydramnios (lack of amniotic fluid), which can lead to umbilical cord compression and abnormal fetal heart rate patterns, such as variable decelerations. An NST in this situation would likely show variable decelerations, indicating potential fetal distress due to cord compression. In contrast, a reactive and reassuring NST (like in option B) would not match this clinical scenario. (D) A preeclamptic patient at 33 weeks gestation with IUGR is undergoing induction of labor: A preeclamptic patient with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) is at increased risk for placental insufficiency and fetal distress. In this situation, an NST could show non-reassuring fetal heart rate patterns, such as decreased variability or late decelerations, indicating fetal compromise. A reactive NST, like the one described in option B, is less likely in such a scenario due to the high risk of placental dysfunction and fetal hypoxia.

choices.text: Ultrasound assessment of fetal breathing movements

questions.text: Your patient complains of decreased fetal movement at term. You recommend a modified BPP test. Nonstress tesng (NST) in your once was reactive. The next part of the modified BPP is which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The BPP consists of five components: Nonstress test 2. Fetal breathing movements—one or more episodes of fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes 3. Fetal movement—three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes 4. Fetal tone—one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand 5. Determination of amniotic fluid volume—a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm

choices.text: Weekly follow up with Doppler studies

questions.text: Primigravida at 32 weeks with intrauterine fetal growth restriction is being monitored with Doppler studies, the following is the finding obtained what is the appropriate management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) UMBILICAL ARETRY DOPPLER with REDF at and beyond 32 weeks is an indication for immediate delivery and these patients will be delivered by CS UMBILICAL ARETRY DOPPLER with AEDF at and beyond 34 weeks are indication for immediate delivery At less than these gestations these pregnancies will be monitored with NST every 12 hrs and daily BPP. If a course of antenatal corticosteroids has not been administered yet it will also be given Iugr babies if the Doppler studies show reduced diastolic flow with signs of UPI like oligohydramnios, preeclampsia then delivery is planned between 34-37 weeks In IUGR babies if umbilical artery Doppler is normal and no risk factors are present then delivery is done at 39-40 weeks
